blog_post.title: What We Know—and What We Don’t Know—About the Impact of the Pandemic on Our Most Vulnerable Community

lede.lede: Residents of nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities suffered an outsized impact from COVID-19. And yet we still don’t know how big of an impact, because so much data is missing or incomplete. What we do know makes plain that we failed to protect this community—and at great cost.

blog_post.title: Cases Stop Dropping and the Midwest Heats Up: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 3

lede.lede: After five straight weeks of sharp declines in new cases of COVID-19 in the United States, we’ve leveled off again. Reported tests are up about 5 percent, but are actually dropping in the Midwest, where three states—Iowa, North Dakota, and South Dakota—are driving an uptick in new cases. This week we also launched a new dataset that looks closely at the toll of COVID-19 in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities.

","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"New York","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" is a good example: the state was the epicenter of the pandemic in its early stages, and its 25,000-plus deaths make up about one-sixth of those nationwide, with about 10,000 more than neighboring ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"New Jersey","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", another early hotspot. But even with its larger population and higher number of COVID-19 cases, New York reports fewer LTC deaths than New Jersey: about 6,300 versus 6,800, and a much lower per-capita count. This is likely because, as mentioned earlier, New York only counts LTC deaths when a patient dies in a facility; New Jersey, like most states, counts deaths connected to LTCs.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"The New York","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":" ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Times","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" explored a common criticism of New York Governor Andrew Cuomo: discharging COVID-19 patients to LTCs in order to alleviate hospital overcrowding spread the disease and may be responsible for New York’s tremendously high death count. But, as the piece notes, “roughly” 12 states did the same, including New Jersey. Connecticut and Massachusetts created COVID-19-only facilities, which was ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/connecticut-launches-bold-new-approach-virus-crisis-covid-19-only-n1204546"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"considered an appropriate response","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", but their per-capita over-65 deaths in LTCs are also quite high. (Seventy percent of deaths in Connecticut are connected to LTCs.) Determining which policies worked—and which didn't work or exacerbated the problem—will be critical for future pandemics, if not for the ongoing one.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Since the first states to suffer from large COVID-19 outbreaks also have the highest per-capita over-65 deaths in LTCs, experts are watching states where cases rose during the summer months. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"LTC cases and deaths in these states are elevated compared to the spring, but may be heading in the right direction since the last August reporting period.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Florida","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" has seen one of the largest recent outbreaks, and deaths have followed during the last three reporting periods.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"7lrLnadwzlFp14CwAQJGsZ","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Texas","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", another large Sunbelt state with a substantial summer outbreak, saw a huge spike in LTC infections during July, with more than half its cumulative cases coming over a two-week period. About a third of its cumulative LTC deaths have occurred since mid-July; fortunately, cases and outbreaks have declined in August, and deaths seem to be on the same trajectory.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"10y4Sgs864CHTaFp6oSSjj","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6v1VxqN88IqqjUbg7dah2U","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Arizona","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" is another point of focus for its ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/all-metrics-per-state"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"recent increases","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths. Unfortunately, the state does not separately report cases or deaths in LTC facilities. It does report facilities with outbreaks cumulatively. That number increased during June and July, while numbers in August are comparable to those in May.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"7zvWQfMyQM6SqeZpxP4hBA","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Georgia","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", LTC cases spiked in July and early August. Recently the state has reported about 1,000 cases a week, about twice as many weekly cases as were reported in late May and the month of June. Cases and deaths fell in the most recent reporting period, closer to late-May levels.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6f1ia9i1DcoZOgoBqZ41mG","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Why did LTC cases and deaths spike in the summer?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"COVID-19’s toll on long-term care facilities was evident early in the pandemic, both abroad and in the Northeast corridor, where the early US outbreaks were most concentrated. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"But despite clear evidence of the virus’ deadly impact on elderly populations, COVID-19 cases and deaths in long-term care facilities grew considerably as the virus spread south and west over the summer","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". Why weren’t the spring's lessons better learned?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The combination of an uneven regulatory landscape—across states and types of facility—and ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"a lack of resources, such as inadequate testing capacity, remains a problem","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/blogs/stateline/2020/07/15/covid-19-testing-falls-short-in-long-term-care-facilities"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"According to Pew’s Stateline","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", “In at least 32 states, at least one round of testing of all long-term care residents and staff has been mandated,” while four states only mandate testing of staff. But ongoing, reliable testing is required to detect and isolate potential outbreaks, and Pew’s Stateline reports significant testing failures: 60 percent of respondents to one survey conducted at the end of June said test results took up to four days. The CEO of one Texas LTC chain told Pew that test results sometimes took up to three weeks, and it cost his company $300,000 a week to test the 4,200 staff and residents in the company’s 31 facilities.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In late April, Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) and Edward Markey (D-MA) began contacting the 11 largest LTC operators in the country to learn about how they are dealing with the pandemic. Last month they released ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.warren.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Assisted%20Living%20Facilities%20Staff%20Report.pdf"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"their findings","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". Operators told the senators that they had sufficient access to testing for symptomatic patients and staff, but not for asymptomatic testing. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"According to the report, “most operators reiterated that CDC guidance does not recommend routine testing,”","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" though the report notes that a May 3 CDC document calls the testing of asymptomatic individuals “appropriate,” including the testing of those without known exposure “for early identification in special settings.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"On July 22, the US Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) began requiring that nursing homes in states with a positivity rate above 5 percent test all staff","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", promising 15,000 testing devices “over the next few months,” ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://news.bloomberglaw.com/health-law-and-business/nursing-home-staff-tests-required-in-covid-surging-states"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"according to","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Bloomberg Law","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". About a week prior, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.mcknights.com/news/cms-to-offer-point-of-care-covid-19-tests-at-nursing-homes/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"CMS announced it","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" was sending 2,000 point-of-care tests to nursing homes, with a goal to supply all 15,400 facilities in the US. Recently, however, the president of the California Association for Long Term Care Medicine ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://talkingpointsmemo.com/muckraker/hhs-sent-rapid-testing-machines-to-nursing-homes-without-direction-resulting-in-mass-confusion"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"told ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Talking Points Memo","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that machines sent to the facilities his organization oversees came without instructions or clear reporting guidelines.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"All the facility operators surveyed by Sens. Warren and Markey said they were able to get personal protective equipment, but that the process was expensive and difficult; several reported costs of $1 million to $2 million a month. Two operators set up regional supply hubs with other companies in order to ease the process; one chartered aircraft to deliver PPE. These are, of course, the very largest operators; smaller facilities may have more difficulty obtaining equipment. According to ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/issue-brief/rising-cases-in-long-term-care-facilities-are-cause-for-concern/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"an analysis","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" of CMS data by the Kaiser Family Foundation, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"at the end of June, 2,700 nursing homes in the US reported PPE shortages","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/24/health/coronavirus-nursing-homes-PPE.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"underline"}],"value":"The New York Times","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":" reports","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that a Federal Emergency Management Agency program aiming to supply 15,000 nonprofit nursing-care facilities—chosen for their lack of resources—with two weeks’ worth of PPE, has resulted in complaints about inadequate and poorly manufactured supplies, and a complete absence of N95 masks. Tamara Konetzka, the University of Chicago health economist who recently presented her research on nursing-home grades to Congress, told the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Times","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that “the federal response to protect one of the most vulnerable populations in the country has been a dismal failure.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"The federal government has also struggled to collect data from long-term care facilities","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.aging.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/COVID-19%20in%20Nursing%20Homes%20Final%20Report.pdf"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"A report","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" critical of the Trump administration from the Senate Special Committee on Aging, which is led by three Democratic senators, notes that the first recorded COVID-19 outbreak in the US occurred at a nursing home in Washington state in late February, but ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"the CMS did not “formally issue requirements for data collection until May 8” and did not report complete data until June 4","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". The federal government doesn’t regulate assisted living facilities and isn’t collecting data on them. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://abcnews.go.com/Health/types-senior-living-homes-facing-coronavirus-striking-disparity/story?id=71482941"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"According to ABC News","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", such facilities have received no direct federal aid or PPE.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In a July 6 piece for ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"The Atlantic","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2020/07/us-repeating-deadliest-pandemic-mistake-nursing-home-deaths/613855/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Olga Khazan explored why","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" states downstream of the early COVID-19 outbreaks were struggling with LTC cases, and found a lack of PPE, especially masks; “poor and delayed data collection”; late and inconsistent testing, especially of asymptomatic patients and staff; and uneven responses and capabilities from states and localities to fill in the considerable gaps left by the federal government’s response.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Khazan contrasted the US’s response with that of Hong Kong, which learned hard lessons from SARS and came into the COVID-19 outbreak with a full month’s supply of face masks and PPE. Unlike in the US, LTC staff in Hong Kong used masks from the outset. Rather than scrambling to decide what should happen to COVID-positive LTC residents, Hong Kong required that all such patients would be put in hospital wards until testing negative twice.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The United States has started to learn some of these lessons as well, and there’s some evidence that recent changes have had a real effect on LTC cases and deaths. But as long as data collection and regulatory oversight remain inconsistent, and as long as personal protective equipment and testing remain in short supply, cases in LTCs may remain difficult to manage.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Acknowledgments","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Many people at the The COVID Tracking Project contribute to the research and data compilation efforts that make the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/longtermcare"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Long-Term Care COVID Tracker","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" possible. Special thanks to the long-term care data entry team that compiles and cleans this data every Thursday.
